item.title: The Briefing: Reckoning for Social Media
item.description:
The Briefing
Jury selection kicks off in Los Angeles tomorrow for a trial that both friends and foes of social media are saying could be existential for the social media industry͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 26, 2026

The Briefing
By Erin Woo

Greetings!

Jury selection kicks off in Los Angeles tomorrow for a trial that both friends and foes of social media are saying could be existential for the social media industryâ€”broadly defined to include Googleâ€™s YouTube as well as Meta Platforms and TikTok. The trial centers on a 19-year-old girl from Chico, Calif. who says her social media addiction led to depression and suicidal thoughts. It will be the first of thousands of claims brought by families who say the companies built products designed to be addictive and harmful to young peopleâ€™s mental health.

Itâ€™s a big deal. The legal proceedings offer techâ€™s critics the best shot theyâ€™ve ever had at holding the companies accountable for the harm theyâ€™ve allegedly caused young people. If the tech firms lose, the cases could also establish a new legal precedent some say could make it too risky to build internet services.Â 

This wonâ€™t be a simple process, however, so donâ€™t expect a quick resolution. The trials comprise two main proceedingsâ€”state trials filed by families and federal trials filed by families as well as school districts, state attorneys general and Native American tribes. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Instagram head Adam Mosseri are both expected to testify in the first trial. Snap CEO Evan Spiegel was also expected to testify in the trial starting tomorrow but Snap settled the case, although the Snapchat owner remains a defendant in other cases.

Both the state and federal cases rest on a fairly novel legal theory, at least as applied to social media companies. Plaintiffs are arguing that the designs of the platforms themselvesâ€”including features like infinite scroll, autoplaying videos and targeted notificationsâ€”are defective and are causing harm to users. Courts could order changes to those features as part of their verdicts, which is what the school districts and state attorneys general are seeking. Some changes to social media platforms are rolling out already. Last week, days after settling the first trial, Snap announced that it would give parents more information on how their kids are using Snapchat. Earlier this month YouTube announced new time limit controls that parents can use to manage their childrenâ€™s viewing.Â 

I should clarify that most of the thousands of cases wonâ€™t go to trial. Instead, both the companies and the plaintiffs will watch what happens in the first few trials, known as bellwether trials. Theyâ€™re intended to give both sides an idea of the merits of their legal claims and of how juries might respond, including how large the damages might be. If the tech companies lose and a precedent is established, the parties could resolve the thousands of pending cases via a global settlement.Â 

That probably wouldnâ€™t be cheap, although itâ€™s difficult to know yet how much money could be at stake if the social media companies lose, lawyers involved in the case told me. The big wild cards include how a jury would determine the cost of a victimâ€™s pain and suffering. In cases where a familyâ€™s child died by suicide and they blame it on the platforms, the case is essentially asking the jury to put a dollar value on a life, as one plaintiffâ€™s lawyer put it. The largest-ever global settlement, with the tobacco industry, resulted in those companies agreeing to pay $206 billion over 25 years, as well as make other changes to their marketing practices.

Of course, big tech companies have deep pockets. Whatâ€™s arguably more far-reaching about these cases is that the plaintiffs are aiming to circumvent social media companiesâ€™ main legal defense: Section 230, which social media companies have used successfully to moderate third-party content on their platforms without being held responsible for the content themselves. Critics of social media, including researchers and lawyers, say social media companies have used Section 230 to skirt responsibility for the impact of their platforms.Â 

However, defenders of Section 230 warn that a plaintiff victory could be an â€œexistential resultâ€ opening social media companies to new areas of liability, especially newer companies that canâ€™t marshall the army of lawyers and resources big tech companies can.Â 

â€œYou might see things like infinite scroll on a timeline or news feed is considered a dangerous design,â€ said Jess Miers, an assistant professor at the University of Akron School of Law who previously worked at Google and the industry group Chamber of Progress. â€œIf these types of designs or features are considered to be negligent or dangerous, you will more than likely see these social media services change in significant ways.â€Â 

For plaintiffs, of course, thatâ€™s the entire point.Â 

Zoomâ€™s New Jet Fuel

Zoom Communications was left for dead, as far as the stock market goes, a few years ago. Having captured seemingly all its potential growth during the pandemic, the stock rocketed and then plunged back to earth. Since 2022 it has mostly bounced around in the $70 to $80 a share rangeâ€”until Monday, when it suddenly jumped 11% to just above $95. According to a Barronâ€™s write-up of a research report by Baird Equity Research, Mondayâ€™s jump was due to Baird pointing out that Zoom holds shares in Anthropic from a few years agoâ€”and they could be worth quite a lot.

Zoom invested in Anthropicâ€™s 2023 Series C round, which raised $450 million at a valuation, according to PitchBook, of $4.65 billion. We donâ€™t know how much Zoom put into the round, but its financial statements for the first half of 2023 show it contributed $51 million to strategic investmentsâ€”very likely the Anthropic investment (as Baird reportedly noted). Fast-forward to today: Anthropic is now in talks to raise money at a $350 billion valuation. Its valuation seems likely to rise further if it goes public, as some have speculated it will.Â 

Itâ€™s little wonder Baird put out a report: Given Anthropicâ€™s soaring value since 2023, Zoomâ€™s stake in it seems likely to be now worth at least a couple billion dollars. For a company with an enterprise value of just $20 billion, thatâ€™s nothing to sneeze at!â€”Martin Peers

In Other News

â€¢Â â€‹â€‹Nvidia invested another $2 billion in AI cloud startup CoreWeave as part of a broader deal in which CoreWeave committed to adopt â€œmultiple generationsâ€ of Nvidia chips, including the upcoming Rubin graphics processing units. The investment more than doubled Nvidiaâ€™s stake in CoreWeave to 11.5%, according to a securities filing.

â€¢Â The EU has opened a formal investigation into Elon Muskâ€™s X over how the social media service has integrated xAIâ€™s Grok AI chatbot. The investigation comes amid an outcry after users were able to prompt Grok to generate sexualized images of real people on X, including minors. X is owned by xAI.

â€¢Â The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday said it planned to open a safety investigation into the activity of Waymo vehicles around school buses in Austin, Tex.

Today in The Informationâ€™s TITV

Check out our latest episode of TITV in which we discuss OpenAIâ€™s premium pricing strategy for its advertising rollout.

Recommended Newsletter

Start your day with Applied AI, the newsletter from The Information that uncovers how leading businesses are leveraging AI to automate tasks across the board. Subscribe now for free to get it delivered straight to your inbox twice a week.


New From Our Reporters

Exclusive

OpenAI Seeks Premium Prices in Early Ads Push

By Ann Gehan and Catherine Perloff

Upcoming Events

Wednesday, January 28 â€” Inside Davos With Jessica Lessin: What Global Leaders Are Focused on Now

Join The Information Founder and Editor-in-Chief Jessica Lessin for a subscriber-only live session drawing on her reporting from the World Economic Forum in Davos.

More details

Tuesday, March 3 â€“ Wednesday, March 4 â€” Off the Racquet: An Exclusive Retreat at Indian Wells

Join The Information for an intimate, two-day experience at Indian Wells, where tech leaders, investors, and innovators come together around a shared love of tennis. Request an invite today.

More details

item.title: Five Takeaways From â€˜Data Center Davosâ€™
item.description:
AI Infrastructure
Last week, the data center industry migrated temporarily to Hawaii for the Pacific Telecommunications Council conference. The eventâ€”like Davos except warmerâ€”is typically where deal talks in the data center business begin and the priorities for the year are set.Â  The sectorâ€™s power brokers are coming off a wild 12 months, bookended by the announcementâ€”during last yearâ€™s conferenceâ€”of the $500 billion Stargate data center project, and by the largest transaction in the industryâ€™s history, the $40 billion acquisition of Aligned Data Centers last fall by a group led by BlackRock. Aligned CEO Andrew Schaap was omnipresent last week, along with senior financiers from Goldman Sachs, Citizens Bank, Apollo and Macquarie. OpenAI arrived with a sizable delegation, including executive Peter Hoeschele and, notably, a large number of lawyers.
Jan 26, 2026

AI Infrastructure
By Anissa Gardizy
Supported by

Last week, the data center industry migrated temporarily to Hawaii for the Pacific Telecommunications Council conference. The eventâ€”like Davos except warmerâ€”is typically where deal talks in the data center business begin and the priorities for the year are set.Â 

The sectorâ€™s power brokers are coming off a wild 12 months, bookended by the announcementâ€”during last yearâ€™s conferenceâ€”of the $500 billion Stargate data center project, and by the largest transaction in the industryâ€™s history, the $40 billion acquisition of Aligned Data Centers last fall by a group led by BlackRock.

Aligned CEO Andrew Schaap was omnipresent last week, along with senior financiers from Goldman Sachs, Citizens Bank, Apollo and Macquarie. OpenAI arrived with a sizable delegation, including executive Peter Hoeschele and, notably, a large number of lawyers.

Hereâ€™s what people were talking about at the event.Â 

2026 Will Be About Execution, Not AnnouncementsÂ 

The Stargate plan kicked off a wave of similarly ambitious declarations throughout 2025, with companies pledging hundreds of billions of dollars for AI infrastructure and racing to lock up gigawatts of power.Â 

I think that era is ending. Data center CEOs say that 2026 will be judged less by what companies announce and more by what they actually deliver. This raises stakes for developers that have made big promises.Â 

With deadlines approaching for projects, delays could mean developers start losing their customers, either because they walk away or because competitors come in to salvage stalled projects. Iâ€™ve heard that investors, as well as cloud providers, are crafting their data center deals to include favorable â€œstep-in rights,â€ meaning they could take over projects if their developer is struggling or costs are rising.Â 

The focus on execution this year could mean that top data center executives will be in high demand, similar to the talent wars over AI researchers.Â 

â€œSome people will be delayed, and the customer will live with it,â€ one data center CEO told me. â€œSome people are going to be delayed, and their project is going to fail.â€

Thatâ€™s not to say the optimism is gone. Mai tais flowed freely, dozens of restaurants were booked for private events, and Alicia Keys even performed a small concert.Â 

Googleâ€™s TPUs Emerging as a ThreatÂ 

For years, Nvidiaâ€™s graphics processing units were the unquestioned, default choice for large-scale AI data centers. But several executives told me that Googleâ€™s tensor processing units have become part of infrastructure planning conversations.

Everyone also senses that Google is aggressively pushing its chip, a trend weâ€™ve written about here and here.Â 

Data center investors in particular like Googleâ€™s approach. It is backstopping the debt and leases of certain TPU facilities so that new entrants such as Fluidstack can more easily get financing. A few people told me they think that might put more pressure on Nvidia to do the same thing. (While Nvidia leases back some of its chips from cloud providers and invests in companies that buy its chips, it hasnâ€™t broadly guaranteed data center project debt or facility leases.)

Also new this year was talk of the cloud startups focusing on Googleâ€™s TPUs. Last year was dominated by cloud startups such as CoreWeave, Crusoe and Lambda that primarily focus on GPUs from Nvidia.Â 

Local Pushback Is Becoming a Real Risk

Some executives said power availability isnâ€™t their biggest concern anymore. Instead, theyâ€™re worried about community resistance to data centers.Â 

That context made OpenAIâ€™s recent announcement about developing â€œcommunity plansâ€ for its Stargate campuses feel less surprising. The move followed a similar effort by Microsoft and reflects mounting concernsâ€”from water usage to electricity pricesâ€”about the impact of data centers.Â 

Industry veteran Hunter Newby, who focuses on expanding internet connectivity, told me heâ€™s largely stopped using the words â€œdata centerâ€ when speaking with local communities, given its growing negative connotation. (â€œCloud pod,â€ anyone?)

New Players Hit the Beach

PTC is often seen as a reunion of industry veterans. This year, a wave of startups crashed the party, sometimes with audacious plans.Â 

Power developer American Terawatt emerged from stealth mode, advertising that it would have 600 megawatts of capacity available by the end of this year, though it didnâ€™t say where.Â 

It was also the first time I heard anyone casually invoke the word â€œterawattâ€â€”a unit 1,000 times larger than a gigawattâ€”in a data center context, which is an apt illustration of where the industryâ€™s ambitions have gone.

Whoâ€™s Looking for Data Center Capacity

Multiple attendees told me they came to Hawaii hoping to secure capacity for near-term projects, only to leave empty-handed. Still, it was interesting to hear who was doing the asking and who they were talking to.

For instance, OpenAI was taking meetings last week with â€œcolocation providers,â€ which essentially offer pre-built data centers to which customers can bring their own server hardware. Today, OpenAI rents its capacity from cloud providers that own the servers.Â 

I also heard last week that the Chinese hyperscalers, including ByteDance, are talking to cloud providers such as Oracle about renting cloud capacity in the U.S. for AI. This is particularly interesting given my colleague Qianer Liuâ€™s recent reporting that the Chinese government is restricting companies from buying Nvidia chips. Maybe those firms will rent the capacity in the U.S. instead?

In other news:

  • SoftBank Group halted talks about a potential acquisition of data center operator Switch, Bloomberg reported.Â 
  • My colleague Ken Brown wrote about â€œdata center inflationâ€ and why it matters.
  • Bytedance has been expanding its cloud business in China, known as â€œVolcano Engine,â€ The Financial Times reported.Â 
  • Construction at Metaâ€™s â€œHyperionâ€ data center in Richland Parish, Louisiana, has garnered attention from the local sheriffâ€™s office, which is focusing on managing the increase in commercial truck traffic. Officials say that they haveÂ detained and releasedÂ some workers to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

A message from Nebius

AI is redefining infrastructure. Nebius is redefining cloud.

The AI era is here, but you're stuck choosing between general-purpose clouds or bare metal that sacrifices simplicity for power. Nebius brings both. Purpose-built for AI from silicon to software, Nebius delivers hyperscaler flexibility with supercomputer performance. Every layer engineered for AI workloads â€” eliminating friction, reducing costs and risk â€” so your team can build and deploy at scale. The ultimate AI cloud.
